body_html: It is very possible that the optimizer gets modified after I tested and added the comments (I'm not exactly sure now -- the code is definitely at least re-organized and I do not recall the use of epsilon_hat clearly) so that the comment might not apply any more. But at the time we test it on Inception (summer 2015), we observe much better performance with large epsilon (e.g. 1.0) than the default values like 1e-8 (which sometimes even causes objective divergence if I remember correctly).
body_text: It is very possible that the optimizer gets modified after I tested and added the comments (I'm not exactly sure now -- the code is definitely at least re-organized and I do not recall the use of epsilon_hat clearly) so that the comment might not apply any more. But at the time we test it on Inception (summer 2015), we observe much better performance with large epsilon (e.g. 1.0) than the default values like 1e-8 (which sometimes even causes objective divergence if I remember correctly).
body: It is very possible that the optimizer gets modified after I tested and added the comments (I'm not exactly sure now -- the code is definitely at least re-organized and I do not recall the use of epsilon_hat clearly) so that the comment might not apply any more. But at the time we test it on Inception (summer 2015), we observe much better performance with large epsilon (e.g. 1.0) than the default values like 1e-8 (which sometimes even causes objective divergence if I remember correctly).
